segments.text: You will.
Would you tell me a little bit about yourself?
All right.
Well, let's begin with your name.
Clinton A. Phillips.
What's the A for?
A stands for Adam.
Okay.
My maternal grandfather's name.
Clinton was my father's middle name.
Anyway, I was born April 10th, Friday, in
a little town called Heaston Furnace, Massachusetts, which dates back, has a furnace, a foundry, which dates back to the Revolutionary War.
But I was only a baby there for maybe six months, and my dad then took a position with Ohio Bell Telephone Company in Cleveland, Ohio, and I grew up
my early years until I was about six years old in Cleveland itself, and then into a series of suburbs, principally Lakewood, Ohio.
I continued to grow through my school years, through junior high, and then moved to North Olmsted, Ohio, where I was drafted into the services, ended up in the
What year was that?
In 1943 in the U.S. Army Air Corps, where I was enticed into being an aviation cadet and did indeed go to Marietta College for five months, giving me the year's equivalent of college.
Then they decided they didn't need any more pilots by the spring of 1944, and I ended

first a machine gunner and then quickly an instructor and really spent most of the rest of my military years as a gunnery instructor, finally being discharged after serving briefly as an MP in Montgomery, Alabama.
Then I returned home and immediately went to Baldwin Wallace College.
in the summer of 46.
And by the end of August 48, I had finished my four years college, counting the Marietta experience.
Almost immediately, within two weeks, I was at Vanderbilt University working on a master's degree.
Never, never wrote a thesis, but
and this was in economics.
Returned then to my home, North Olmstead, to be on the faculty of Baldwin Wallace College, my bachelor's alma mater, for two years.
Then back to Vanderbilt, where by 1956 I finished a Ph.D. in economics.
Whereupon I went to teach at the University of Tennessee in the Economics Department for four years.
Then left to join the College of the School of Business Administration at Tulane University in 1958.
And were the business colleges just getting started about that time, the whole concept of
Well, this one dates back to the turn of the century, the one at Tulane.
But business colleges and schools in those days were highly descriptive.
Really, their enrollments weren't very large.
But business administration, through in part the impact of two major studies, one by the Ford Foundation, one by the Rockefeller Foundation,
which were highly critical of what was going on in business administration.
The field of business administration went through a remarkable transformation.
So when did you get to Tulane?
Went to Tennessee in 1954.
Judy and I married in 1953.
He's made that connection.
I met her at Vanderbilt.
In 1967, I was enticed to leave Tulane.
New Orleans was a, parenthetically I should note that New Orleans is a difficult place to raise children.
And we had two children by then.
And so we were intrigued by the rural environment here.
Our daughter was very much into horses.
And so it seemed like a good idea.
I was also impressed by the fact that the American Association of University Professors listed Texas A&M for a couple of years there as offering the highest increases in salaries of any.
Not of any, but it was in the top 10 in terms of salary increases.
That was impressive for those of us teaching in Louisiana.
Yes.
About that time.
Wasn't it, though?
Yes, it was.
You were there, sure.
So, over we came.
You must have come around that same time.
Okay.
And a $3,500 raise.
I thought that was a monstrous amount of money.
I left there.
I was acting dean of the School of Business, and I came here for a couple thousand dollars.
Several thousand.
And it was a lot of money.
It was a lot of money.
It was a lot of money in those days, yes.
It really was.
Well, it was obvious that I have to give a lot of credit to Earl Rudder.

Earl Rudder was out to put this institution on a map, and it wasn't too many years before, of course, that membership at the undergraduate level in the Corps of Cadets was no longer mandatory, and women had been...
The bar had been lifted on women.

Not too many years after I came here, after the death of Earl Rudder and the arrival of President Jack Kenny Williams, women's dormitories were built, and then I think a substantial growth era was ushered in.
When you came, you were dean, associate dean?
No, I came as a full professor.
As a full professor.
In the Department of Management.
OK. Not head, as a full professor.
Who was the dean?
Well, remember, it wasn't a college.
It wasn't, yeah.
The director was John Pearson.
Within, I guess, a year or so, it became a college.
And within another year, 1969, Pearson had hired a person to be head of the finance department.
And on the Friday preceding class, not enrollment, but first day of classes on Monday, this chap wrote and said he couldn't come, or telegraphed to say he couldn't come.
And John Pearson asked me to serve as acting department head.
Well, that developed into a lasting relationship for nearly eight years in January of 76, 77?
I have to work it out anyway.
We can check it out.
That's OK.
I had double bypass surgery, so I stepped down.
And I was going to step down anyway, because two four-year terms were up.
And we had in the college a rule about no more than two four-year terms, a rule not observed necessarily in other colleges, as you know.
Then after the surgery, I taught just as a professor for a year, and then was asked to serve as acting dean.
And that would have been 78, 79, I guess.
Pearson left at that time, or I'm trying to remember that.
He left shortly afterwards.
He went down to 3D International.
That's the right name.
I became associate dean under Bill Muse.
We, in the meantime, had recruited Bill Muse to become a dean.
And in about April or May, effective July 1, I became dean of faculties in 1980, where I remained until August 31.
Now, would you mind telling me a little bit about the purpose and intent of the dean of faculty's position, as you recall?
Because it had just been relatively recently created.
Yeah, I was the second dean of faculty's.
You will recall that Haskell Monroe was the first.
And apparently, that job was in part created
President Jack Williams because he was so impressed by the welcoming address given by Haskell representing the faculty at President Williams' inauguration.
And so he was in for four or five years, I guess.
I don't have to check that out.
And so when I came in, there were just
the vice president for academic affairs, Mack Prescott, and Charles McCandless, who was associate vice president.
My title, I should back up, Haskell's title had been associate dean of faculties and associate vice president.
That position was split, and McCandless became associate
vice president for academic affairs, and I became dean of faculties then.
I was not in office but a few months when Jarvis Miller, I don't know how you want to put it, resigned or was asked to resign by the board.
I think it was around
Anyway, July or August, July meeting, I guess, this occurred.
And for a year, Chuck Sampson was president, which would take him through August of 81, at which time Frank Vandiver became president.
And not too long thereafter, I was once again given the title of dean of faculties and associate vice president.
And Chuck left about that time.
No, he didn't leave.
Oh, he didn't.
He didn't leave for several years.
Mac Prescott stepped down a year or so along with Howard Vestal about the same time as vice president.
Vestal was vice president for finance.
And Chuck served as acting vice president for a year.
Gordon Eaton became provost at that time.
The title, provost, was added.
I guess it was at that time that I became an additional associate provost.
Those are really changing times, I guess.
Seventy, what, six to eighty, whatever, five, it's always changed.
They were dynamic times.
Of course, the times
The real changes began when Windman came in, and there were only a handful when you and I were there at first.
Sure were.
I still remember my first class.
Yeah.
And Williams, an unsung hero, I think, of this institution, at least not appropriately recognized with John C. Calhoun, who was the vice president for academic affairs, was he who
initiated our becoming and saw that we did become a Sea Grant University.
He brought in people like George Bass, Archaeology, and the big growth started.
So, I think there were like 10,500
11,000 students.
When you came in 67.
When I came in 67.
That'd be about right, because it was around 12 or 13 when I got here in 69.

And I'll never forget in what was then called the Academic Council, while General Rutter was still alive, hearing him speculate as he presided over this as to what caps we should put on the size of the institution.
I remember that in discussions, yeah.
The figure of 15,000 or maybe 17,500 or 18,000.
would be a nice number.
Never happened.
It never happened.
I think we were so growth-minded and, I suppose, influenced by the enormous size of UT and a desire to be big.
I think I asked Mandon for that question.
I said, did the board really want to keep up with Texas?
Is that what it was all about?
I don't know how you responded.

I remember when talking with Haskell Monroe as he was leaving and I was coming in, and he left pretty quickly, so I think he and I overlapped a week maybe, so I didn't really have a long learning period.
But anyway, I remember asking Haskell about what are the chances of capping growth, and I won't quote the particular regent, but he said, that'll be over my dead body.
Yeah, sure.
He's still with us.
But eventually we did, of course, at 41,000 a few years ago.
What was your primary mission or function as a dean of faculties?
And how would you describe the changing character, I guess, of the faculty as you've seen it?
Well, in part,
Obviously, I represented the faculty to the administration, I suppose.
That was the role that I felt I inherited.
Probably the most important single function that I performed was to manage the process of tenure and promotion, which became increasingly rigorous.
Mack Prescott certainly moved in that direction.
Gordon Eaton introduced
the concept of requiring outside letters.
And so the process became increasingly rigorous and, I have to say, more bureaucratized as we tried to make it as fair as possible, both for the faculty and for the administration.
So that was certainly important.
Also, of course, as did Haskell before me, I suppose,
I listened to complaints that faculty had and tried to do something about them.
OK, let me ask, what kind of complaints did faculty have?
Was there any single orientation to those complaints?
Well, many of them emanated from they're not getting tenure.
That's a time when folks started getting turned down in greater percentages.
Those are hard, aren't they?
For tenure and promotion, they really are.
They were heart-wrenching.
And we didn't inform faculty adequately.
There was a notable lack of counseling on the part of department heads on the subject of whether they were progressing satisfactorily to our tenure.
As a department head, you would be well aware of this.
There were problems associated with the fact that turnover would occur, and a person would believe he or she was doing well under Department Head A, but under B, the game changed.
And this brought about further bureaucratization by requiring that there be an advisory committee for the Department Head.
to provide, we hoped, some continuity.
I can recall an incident where two fellows served under three different department heads and three different deans in the space of six years, with varying signals being given to them.
So that was a problem.
Salary complaints.

A major one which ultimately ended up in a trial that was decided only finally a couple of years ago about a foreign national who felt that because he was a foreign national he had been discriminated against.
There were cases of females feeling that they were discriminated against.
I got increasingly involved in the sexual harassment
issues, which was a very tricky kind of thing because our early efforts led to sort of letting people go quietly away, and that always bothered me.
When did you first become aware of sexual harassment as a problem in that community?
This had always been there.
It had been there.
But it never would have been overt.
We hadn't had very many women, of course, until the mid-'70s.
And for the most part, they just put up with it, apparently.
There were some pretty salty characters that had been at the institution for some time.
And some of them used language, which
women found offensive.
Some were actually, you know, what's a woman doing here kind of thing.
So there was gender harassment.
Certainly that must have been fairly strong.
Of course, we had at least a perception of that in the Department of History.
Yes, yes.
And then some of the colleges which had been so male-dominated, agriculture and engineering, for example, it was a problem.
I do not recall it to be much of a problem.
in the College of Business, but it was such a young college.
Only a handful of, quote, old-timers were there, because the school grew so fast.
You recall in the war years, it was part of the College of Agriculture, and it had been called part of liberal arts.
Were you, how about affirmative action as a part of your role?
That came in certainly with
Frank Vandiver, who was very much interested in that.
I like to think that I played a, and I know I played a supportive role and an encouraging role along with the President and others in upper level administration to support the creation of the Senate.
Yeah, okay.
And the Faculty Senate, do you think the Faculty Senate markedly changed the
complexion or character of whatever, the A&M, the academia?
Yes, I think it did.
I think.
As a more democratic society or what?
Yes, I think more democratic, more sensitive to issues that affected faculty.
Did it improve recruiting?
Did it improve?
I think it did.
I think it did, yes.
How about ultimately teaching the quality of the educational process?
I think so.
The Faculty Senate spent a substantial amount of time developing a document which then became appended to the tenure and promotion document of the university, which sought to identify qualities
for teaching, research, and service that I think informed our process, made it better in evaluating tenure track and tenured faculty for promotion.
The pendulum may have gone
too far for a while in terms of national reputation criteria, in particular publication, without sufficient latitude to recognize the really outstanding teacher who was not doing as much research.
Interestingly enough, if you look at the records, you'll find a not
small number of people who have gotten both the former Students Association outstanding teaching and research awards.
And research, which is the way it should be.
Matter of fact, I'm proud to say I hired two people in the Department of Finance who got both awards.
Yeah, that's where it's supposed to work.
But back to your question about the Senate, yes, I think it would have come anyway, but it's certainly...
Probably in a more bloody year.
It might have been a more bloody thing.
The fact that the president...
Stuck his neck out, because there wasn't a lot of support, certainly in the board, in my opinion.
Yeah, he mentioned specifically, as I recall, engineering as not being too enthusiastic.
And agriculture, too.
Faculty centers, yeah.
Yeah.
Well, if we could talk on the record for a minute, we might better not.
But the Senate opened up...
a willingness on the part of the powers that be to accept a lot of things, such as a faculty club, which could offer alcoholic beverages.
And there was some concern about that.
But it came to be.
And I think it serves a useful function.
And I was pleased to be involved with it.
with that development, too.
Did you feel like you were caught sometimes between the faculty and the administration?
Oh, yes.
That's a tough spot you're in.
No.
The job is one of being an ombudsperson.
And I was caught in a number of ways.
And any dean of faculties is caught in a number of ways in that it's not only between the faculty and the administration, but it's between, well,
I had to be very careful talking with a faculty member who hadn't gone through proper channels through his department head or his dean.
Sometimes all I could do was say, look, we've got to come out in the open if we're going to try to address this issue.
Are you willing to do that?
And if they weren't, then there wasn't much I could do.
But a lot of times I could.
There were some cases in one college, particularly, where people were arbitrarily moved from one department to another without consultation.
And we did blow the whistle on that.
I mean, it was just wrong.
So we had to dismantle some decisions on the part of the dean and a director.
And so sometimes it got kind of tough.
But it was a tension-ridden job.
I don't think it would be.
I don't see, quite frankly, how you survived as well and as unflappably as you did.
I never saw you lose your temper, which is incredible.
Well, I came home sometimes in a pretty bad shape.
I bet you did.
But sometimes things were just so, you know, you just wondered how people could treat other people like that.
Sometimes people would be named department heads and then begin to act like dictators.

Oh, that's what I want to ask you about, too, about the headship and about what might be the unique administrative structures at A&M, if they are even now, or maybe they've changed, you think, to conform pretty much to the... Headship is fairly common.
in state institutions.
Chairmanship, much more common in private institutions.
But I think increasingly heads here have operated like chairs.
Yeah, I think so too.
With a consent of the...
There was, I think, over the years, an increasing recognition of the fact that faculty members
are equals with a dean or with a department head.
And the mere fact that they don't have an administrative title tacked on doesn't mean that they can be treated like a typical employer, employee.
Faculty members are, particularly those who do establish a national reputation, are indeed free agents.
You know, the early years of this institution, most of the folks were indeed focused very much on teaching, with no little exceptions.
But they really didn't have anywhere to go if they didn't like the way things were.
Whereas in the 70s and 80s, that changed dramatically.
How about the student body?
How has it changed, do you think, over your 25 years or so, 30 years that you've been?
Politically, it still remains ultra-conservative, I think.
I think that it's remarkable when you look at the election returns from the ballot boxes on campus.
Students, I think, now, though, feel much more free to express themselves.
to disagree with a professor.
And I think that's healthy.
OK. You would say there's a greater what?
A diversity or?
Greater diversity.
License?
That's not the word.
But I know what you're saying.
I'll work with it, too.
There's greater academic freedom among the students as well as among the faculty, perhaps.
What about the core?
I guess I need to ask that question.
Well, you'll recall when you and I first came, the core really was dominant.
I once remarked to somebody that when one walked across the campus, one felt propelled on a sea of howdies.
And of course, that has the core diminished.
And I suppose the Vietnam War had an impact on the size of the core.
I'm trying to remember how many students there were in it when I came.
I would think at least half, but I don't know, or better.
All I can remember is my freshman class.
Over in physics, I had 130 students.
And I know at least almost all of them in uniform, and one female.
Most of the students in uniform were asleep.
I still remember that.
Oh, my gosh.
What's going on?
I finally found out.
They'd been up all night and nights before.
Yeah, being harassed.
Well, another thing, do you remember, or had it disappeared by the time you came, that incredibly wacky teaching schedule one would have of Monday and Wednesday at 9 o'clock?
Yeah, that went out about Thursday of the first year or something like that.
Oh, wasn't that wacky?
I mean, yeah.
That was very hard to keep up with.
I get confused.
It really was.

Particularly if you're teaching the same class as often one was, twice or maybe even three times, you'd have a class meeting for 50 minutes Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, and another class meeting for an hour and 50 minutes.
Well, I guess we're still doing that, aren't we?
Well, on Tuesday, Thursday.
Tuesday, Thursday.
Tuesday, Thursday, yeah.
I used to find that frustrating.
But it was really crazy back when you had that crazy.
Yeah, that other.
You know, unless you kept your wits about you, which I never did.
I still don't.
You could end up getting on the wrong track.
Because here it was afternoon, and you taught a 1 o'clock, Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, and now you're, oh, well.
That's why I stick to Monday, Wednesday, Friday, 8, 10, and 11 if I have to have the third class or something like that.
How would you rate the attitude or character of the A&M student body as you might compare it to other Texas or other university student bodies?
Well, if you look at the numbers, they're big.
And if you look at their admission scores and so forth, now certainly there is
approximately the same as the University of Texas.
I found the students to be pretty good students when I came here, when I stayed awake.
Yeah, I do too.
Tulane was kind of an exclusive school, with a lot of students from New York, by the way.
I didn't realize that.
Yeah, there really was.
But in any event, I was pleased with the caliber of the students.
It bothered me that they seemed to refrain from asking questions as much as I would have liked.
I did not find the graduate students as good.
I was appalled the first year I was here.
I had two flagrant cases of plagiarism on the term papers at the graduate level.
and was dismayed to learn that neither of these graduate students had ever written a term paper before.
That was a chronic problem.
And didn't know what plagiarism was.
I didn't flunk them out, which I would have at Tulane, because they knew better under the honor code there.
I was surprised we didn't have an honor code here.
Tulane did.
You're right.
Sure.
Yeah.
I guess the Corps somehow or other hadn't had that covered.
I don't know.
How about the Aggie syndrome or whatever, you know, as being the hayseed, the engineering Aggie characterization?
Was that, did you ever feel that was appropriate or inappropriate?
Yeah.
You heard the expression a lot in those early days of a goat roper.
Yeah.
You never hear it anymore.
No.
You still see the occasional student with his, well,
quite a few with boots, cowboy hats, but it was much more prevalent.
It's kind of even nice to see them now.
Yeah, I enjoy it.
It's diversity, and I think it's kind of fun.
Judy, I thought, was going to be gone a lot longer.
She's been over registering graduates.
I said, come on, man.
Oh, really?
This guy's going to act like he's got to have affection now.
Well, yeah, they were.
I suppose in those days, a lot of them were from rural areas.
But this estate is a highly urbanized state now.
Yeah.
And you know, one thing is, statistically, all A&M students have always come from Monk.
Hi.
How are you doing?
OK. How are you?
The job didn't last long.
No, it didn't.
My job.
Under Vandiver, there really was a strong effort to increase minority faculty.
And he was successful in getting the board to appropriate significant sums of money.
Now, what we did was, for a year or two, offer a
a position to a department if they could find a qualified minority.
You remember that?
I used it.
I'm sure you did.
Everybody did.
When we cut back to 50%, because we were getting hard up for money, the effort declined somewhat.
But in any event, that was certainly a phenomenon that I was involved with and encouraging.
the money available was administered through my office.
So that was a new task that Haskell never had.
Sexual harassment probably wasn't something he had to deal with very much.
It just got more noticeable.
You were on a lot of the committees also.
Search committees, and all kinds of others.
Curriculum committee, graduate studies committee.
Chaired the search committees for Jiminy, dean of liberal arts twice, dean of engineering.
Herb, the committee that brought Herb in, I chaired.
Science, medicine.
I chaired geosciences when Gordon Eaton came, and then twice I chaired, or three times I chaired vice president committees.
Were you, when the medical college began, how much involvement did you have?
It was in existence when I came in.
Bob Stone was dean.
In fact, Stone was on the committee that recommended me to the,
to the president and vice president for my position.
Although I did chair the committee that brought Rich Duvall here.
Very broadly speaking, what did you see in the last 10 or 15 years, the great strengths and the great confrontations or difficulties that the university encountered?
What's the greatest problem, let's say?
Let's start with that, the tough things.
The tough things have been to increase the diversity in the faculty.
That certainly was tough.
When you've got this military heritage and all that goes with it, I suppose
there was abroad in the land a reluctance to even consider coming here.
And we continue to operate under a severe disadvantage because of the community.
This is not a congenial place for a minority to live.
It's not that it's, it's not, I shouldn't say congenial, but it's just that there is no infrastructure, middle class, blacks particularly, and not much of a
I'm an Hispanic middle class.
I don't know if you had much involvement with them, but did you have any sense of support or opposition from former students in these changes at work?
Well, there was, you will recall, considerable difficulty.
I don't think not with bringing in minorities, no.
Where we had problems was with foreign
teachers and teaching assistants.
Math, particularly.
Oh, math, yes.
Elton Lacy did a marvelous job of capturing the mamas, but they dissented en masse on us with their complaints.
And of course, a student who wasn't doing well could always use this as an excuse.
And it is true.
that Indians, particularly in Orientals, are sometimes difficult.
Good at math and not too good at the languages.
That's right.
That's right.
Yeah.
Well, you know, we had that problem with Zoltan.
Even in our department, we were Zoltan Kastami.
And I kept telling the students, you'll just sit there one week.
You'll love him.
And they did.
Yeah.
That first day, a lot of them were just deaf.
They could not understand.
Just getting used to it.
But he was a good teacher.
Are there other confrontational problems, difficulties that the university really faced that you...
There was opposition over the Senate.
There was, you recall, the committee that Sam Black chaired to revise the curriculum was kind of a sticky wicket for a while.
Certainly the issue of
of seniors having to take the final exams was a sticky wicket.
One after another, these little traditions got knocked down, and so that kind of distressed some people.
The issue of gays, I was not involved.
The student problems were
issues were not issues that I really got involved with.
Yeah, yeah.
Well, that's someone I'm going to try to interview.
It's John Coldis, too.
I need to talk to him about some of those activities.
Then there were, oh, there was a longstanding bureaucratic
stuffiness about doing things the way they had always been done.

I shall never forget when I was a department head, my secretary being absolutely inflamed by the fact that someone in the business offices of the university returning an envelope that had not been folded the correct way, so that
open the envelope could be to get at the form inside.
And I called the then comptroller.
Now, I came out of a place where a professor was a professor, and if you didn't like things, you'd call whoever was responsible.
And so this was 20 years ago, I guess.
I think it was Clark Diebel I called.
I was so angry about that.
I said, don't these people understand why they've got a job?
You know, that kind of thing.
I'll never forget another thing.
This is an aside, but it illustrates the kind of bureaucratic attitude.
Graduate students failing to get paid on time and being forced.
And the local banks giving them non-interest loans.
Why should the banks have to pay for the incompetence of the university?
Yes, of the administration, yeah.
Well.
That was always.
Damn.
And new faculty coming and not getting their paychecks on time.
Unconscionable.
Well, that happened to me when I first came, as a matter of fact.
And Milton, of all people, is usually on top of everything.
And I didn't even dare ask, though.
For several weeks, at least, and finally I said, when do I get paid?
He said, you're not paid.
I said, well.
I imagine he did something about it.
He did something about it instantly, but still.
Dave Maxwell told me that, well, no.
Milton was something of a curmudgeon.
Nonetheless, he was protective of his faculty.
He took care of the faculty.
He really did.
They didn't appreciate it all that much, but he did.
In fact, I think there was a time there when the Department of History salary level scale was about as good as any department in the university, only because of Milton Nance.
I doubt that it's held that since then.
One of the real fun parts of my job was I inherited the chairmanship of the A&M Press Committee, which is always a joy.
That's a good point.
I need to flag the press, too, in this revision, which sometimes I forget about.
Yeah, that has been a nice thing to do.
What about the legislature now?
Did you ever go to the legislature?
Did you go to the board meetings?
Yeah, under Vanderburg and Miller, a lot of people went to the board meetings.
Under Mobley and even before that, I guess, the board got a little tired of having a mob scene and most of us just stood around.
waited outside while the board deliberated in private and that sort of thing.
And I went, oh, I suppose maybe a half dozen times to the legislature just in case they'd ask a question about something and you'd be there to respond.
But for the most part, it was a waste of time.
What about A&M's funding generally and the competition between A&M and University of Texas while you were?
We fared pretty well up until the mid-80s and then things started getting tight when OPEC fell apart.
If you look at the funding, I don't know if you want to get into this, but Danny Parker could give you quite a good picture of what's happened to funding in the mid-'80s.
The state is appropriating not much more than appropriating in 1986 to the university.
Increasingly, we have had to use the available fund not just for faculty and not for excellence.
Just to survive.
But just to survive.
I think when I went in,
in 1980, probably the appropriation from the legislature, and you'd want to check this, was on the order of 50% of our total operating budget.
It's down under like 36% or 7% now.
That's why.
That's a good point.
Yeah.
Yeah.
That's why.
And I don't want to make a big issue of it, but it's interesting.
I think it's .
